text: Introduction to TDA 3.2. Homology 3.2.4 Homology Groups We are now ready to formalize the notion of holes or cavities. Recall that intuitively, a hole is a cycle that is not a boundary, that is, not filled by something higher-dimensional. Using that all objects defined so far form abelian groups, we can phrase this in algebraic terms using quotient groups. Definition 3.26. The p-th homology group H (K) is the quotient group Z (K)/B (K). p p p Often in the literature we write H (K;R) for homology over some ring R. Since we p only work with homology over Z in these lecture notes, we just write H (K) to mean 2 p H (K;Z ). p 2 Remember that the elements of a quotient group are cosets. In essence, each element of the homology group is a coset called a homology class which contains cycles that differ only by boundaries. The coset [c] = c+B is the homology class of c. We say that p c and c′ are homologous, if [c] = [c′], which is equivalent to the statements c ∈ c′ +B p and c+c′ ∈ B .
